title: If the length is increased by 35%, by what percent should the width of a rectangle be decreased so as to keep the area the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: Area of rectangle is A = L x W If A is a constant (assigned factor value 1) and the length is increase 35% a factor y=1.35, zW*(1.35L)=1A where z is the factor for the width We have zy=1, z=1/y, 1/1.35= 0.74. W has to measure 0.74 or 26% less to keep the same area when L is increased by 35%

look L is increased by 35% (1.35 * L )*(1-x)*w = area = L*w x is percentage to be decreased in width : w x = 1-(1/1.35) must be decreased to keep area the same x=0.259 so the width should be decreased by 26%
Area of rectangle =L×B sq units where L is Length,B is width Let X be deceased width Length increased to= 1•35 L L×B=1•35 L×X X=B/1•35=•74B % decrease in width= {(B--•74B)/B}×100=26%
